note: These are questions on electric circuits waiting for a home in some pod

questions.text: The resistance of an ammeter is _______

questionList.text: An ammeter does not have a measurable resistance.

questions.text: The resistance of a voltmeter is _______

questionList.text: A voltmeter does not have a measurable resistance.

questions.text: A student connects a multimeter to measure the voltage across a 1000 Ohm resistor connected to a single D battery. After determining a valid measurement (1.5 volts), he applies Ohm's Law and determiens the current should be 0.0015 A. But when he switches the ammeter to measure current, he finds a current of 15 A! Which of the following statements is true?
questions.note: add two photos to this problem....

questionList.text: The student measured the current correctly; either the resistor or the multimeter must be defective.
The student needs to change how the meter is connected in order to receive an accurate measurement for current.
The student measured current the accurately but applied Ohm's Law incorrectly.

questions.text: A student applies Ohms law to a circuit with a single battery connected to an ammeter with no resistor. She concludes that the current will be infinite. When a student connects an ammeter in such a way, she finds a current of 10 A, which means the resistnace must be ____. Where is most of this resistance coming from?

questionList.text: She is connecting the ammeter incorrectly.

questions.text: A (not too bright) physics student connects three car batteries in series for a total voltage of approximately 36 Volts. He then concludes that, because the current from a wall outlet is 120 Volts and the current from the batteries is 36 Volts, it is safe to use and proceeds to connect it to a relatively weak resistor. Very bad things result. What is the student not considering?

questionList.text: The chemicals in car batteries make them more dangerous than other devices.
The wall outlet gives Alternating current and the batteries produce a Direct Current; DC current is more dangerous at lower magnitudes tha AC current
